awd_titl_txt: Negative sea ice-circulation feedback along Arctic marginal ice zones
awd_abstract_narration:
It is increasingly important to understand how sea ice interacts with the overlying atmospheric circulation. Funds are proided to investigate a negative feedback process over and around the Arctic marginal ice zone (MIZ) involving variability in sea ice, surface heat flux, and surface wind stress. In this negative feedback process, sea ice anomalies in the MIZ are hypothesized to generate local wind patterns that act to counter the initial sea ice anomalies, providing a regulatory mechanism on the retreat and advance of the MIZ on weekly time scales.

This work will quantify the MIZ local negative feedback process and determine its effects under contemporary and projected sea ice conditions. A detailed three-year study in observations and modeling environments will realize the following research objectives: 1) determine and map the response of surface wind stress to sea ice extent anomalies in the MIZ, 2) determine and map the sea ice response to wind stress anomalies generated by local sea ice anomalies, 3) evaluate the statistical significance of the sea ice-wind stress negative feedback in observations and coupled simulations, and 4) determine the effects of the feedback by turning it on and off in a coupled model. 

This project will provide research support for a new, young investigator, as well as support for the additional training of a female graduate student and an undergraduate student.  The project also includes outreach to k-12 students.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on processes that control changes in one of the most important components of the climate system – sea ice. Models and observations were used to investigate feedback processes that change how sea ice and the overlying atmosphere behave. One of the most well-known feedbacks in the climate system is the sea ice-albedo feedback: warming of the climate system causes sea ice to melt; melting reduces the planet’s reflection of sunlight; more incoming sunlight encourages more warming and hence more melting, and so on. This feedback is positive in sign because an initial warming sets off a series of processes that lead to more warming. If warming instead set off a series of processes that led to cooling, the feedback would be negative in sign. There is great interest in identifying the strength and sign of feedback loops because they heavily influence the magnitude of variations and changes in the climate system such as global warming.

The title of the project indicates that we set out to study a negative feedback between the atmosphere and sea ice. We did uncover and understand this negative feedback, but were surprised to see it outweighed by a stronger accompanying feedback that was positive in sign. To illustrate both feedbacks, consider a reduction in sea ice over a portion of the Arctic. The reduction in sea ice increases upward heat flow into the atmosphere because the exposed ocean is warmer than the previously present sea ice. The atmosphere therefore becomes warmer, and the associated change in pressure generates an overlying inward wind pattern that moves the ice to partially cover up the opened ocean (the negative feedback). Meanwhile, the warmed atmosphere acts as a heat source that enhances ice melt from above and hence tends to open the ocean more (the positive feedback). Careful separation and extensive study of these two processes in a hierarchy of modeling frameworks (Liptak and Strong, 2013, 2014a-c) showed that the positive component dominates, and this “ice-atmosphere” feedback acts to substantially increase variability in the sea ice and the overlying atmosphere.

The ice-atmosphere feedback operates within the marginal ice zone  (MIZ) – the broken portion of the sea ice cover adjacent to the open ocean, and work on this project inspired development of an objective measure for the width of the MIZ (Strong 2012). The width of the MIZ is a fundamental length scale for Arctic climate, impacting wave processes, atmospheric processes, marine habitat selection, and human accessibility to the Arctic. Defining an objective measure of MIZ width led to the discovery that the warm-season MIZ has widened by a striking 39% over the past several decades (Strong and Rigor, 2013).

This project’s study of feedbacks within the MIZ was made possible by customizing a state-of-the-science climate model that simulates interactions between ocean, sea ice, atmosphere, and land components (the National Center for Atmospheric Research Community Earth System Model). Specifically, the portions of the model code that regulate exchanges of energy between the atmosphere and surface were modified so that aspects of the sea ice-atmosphere feedback could be enabled or suppressed as needed for each of the experimental designs. The project provided a scientific framework for a graduate student’s successful dissertation, and she is coauthor on five associated manuscripts and five conference presentations. Data and findings from the project were used in outreach to high school classrooms and were used to enhance polar learning modules for the Principal Investigator’s university courses on climate.

References

Liptak J, Strong C. (2014c) A modeling investigation of the Arctic sea ice-atmosphere feedback, Climate Dynamics, under peer review.
